title: Nicole Scherzinger explains what the Australian slang term SULA means
text:
She's a judge on three different talent shows across three continents, including Australia's Got Talent, filmed Down Under.

And on Thursday, Nicole Scherzinger revealed she picked up what she thought was some of the local slang while filming in Australia.

During an appearance on The Kelly Clarkson Show, the former Pussycat Doll, 41, attempted an Australian accent as she revealed the word.

'It's called SULA!' Nicole Scherzinger (left) appeared on The Kelly Clarkson Show on Thursday and revealed a slang term she learned in Australia. But do Aussies actually use it?

'I learned a new word in Australia. So, this is what's keeping me motivated. I learned "sula". Does anyone know what a sula is?' Nicole said.

'If you don't have a sula, you're not working hard enough. A sula is a sweaty upper lip alert. So, you've got to work so hard.'

The talent show judge motioned to her upper lip, explaining that sweat indicates effective training - while continuing her questionable Australian accent.

Okay Nicole! 'If you don't have a sula, you're not working hard enough. A sula is a sweaty upper lip alert. So, you've got to work so hard' she explained

Awkward! Although Nicole learnt about the acronym 'sula' in Australia, it is actually a reference to the 2008 movie Wild Child starring Emma Roberts (pictured)

'I call that the Whitney!' Kelly Clarkson jokingly replied, referencing singer Whitney Houston's passionate performances.

Although Nicole learnt about the acronym 'sula' in Australia, it is actually a reference to the 2008 movie Wild Child starring Emma Roberts.

In the film, Emma's character Poppy stands up to her school bully Harriet after an intense Lacrosse showdown.

'Don't try and hide it, honey! We've got ourselves a sula... Sweaty upper lip alert!' Poppy says.

No sula here! Nicole was in Sydney to film Australia's Got Talent earlier this year. She noticed how Australian say 'heaps' instead of 'lots of'

Kelly praised Nicole's Australian accent, prompting a self-aware Nicole to reply: 'It's rubbish! But thank you, anyway!'

Earlier in the episode, the 41-year-old proved she had picked up on how Australians often use the word 'heaps' instead of 'lots of'.

'The Australian accent is good times guys. It's heaps, heaps of fun!' Nicole said.

'It's sexy! It's sexy!' Kelly replied.
description: She's a judge on three different talent shows across three continents, including Australia's Got Talent, filmed Down Under.
authors: Shive Prema For Daily Mail Australia
